bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to William B. Bean, January 19, 1951

div1.p: Hench agrees that Bean should suggest that the University of Virginia commemorate the centennial of Reed's birth, and offers to help in any way possible.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to William B. Bean, January 19, 1951
div1.opener:
y f
January 19, 1951
Dr. William B. Bean
State University of Iowa
Department of Internal Medicine
University Hospitals
Iowa City, Iowa
My dear Bill:
div1.p:
I think it would be very nice indeed if you would suggest to your
colleagues at the University of Virginia that there be this year
some appropriate ceremonies in honor of Walter Reed.

I have forgotten the year of his birth but I do know that last year
was the 50th year of his beginning the work on yellow fever in Cuba.
They actually finished their work in 1901 rather than 1900 so that
this year is the 50th anniversary of the end of their work and next
year is the 50th anniversary of Reed's death.

I have given a lecture on Walter Reed at the University of Virginia.
I think it would be wiser for you, an alumnus, to suggest this
rather than me, an outsider, to do so but I should be delighted to
help in any way possible and you have my permission in your cor-
respondence to say at the appropriate time something like this: “I
am sure that Doctor Hench, a student of the life of Walter Reed,
would be glad to help in any way possible.” The Librarian at the
University of Virginia is especially a Reed fan.

It might actually tie in with the plans of the University to do
this because when I was there three or four years ago they were
hoping to tie in the name of Walter Reed with some of their memorial
building projects. I expect to visit my brother at the University
of Virginia about February 11.

I tried last year to stimulate some writers to write articles in
the popular press calling attention to the 50th anniversary of the
conquest of yellow fever. I asked Steven Spencer of the SATURDAY
EVENING POST, but the POST had done a story on Moran and Reed just
a few years ago and decided not to repeat the story. I tried to
interest two or three others and sent them some background material
but the only thing that came of it was that Mr. Frank Carey of the
Associated Press did write a story which was syndicated in a great
many Sunday papers. Of course in these momentous times of tension
very little of the world is interested in looking back and con-
sidering historical matters. There is too much history in the
making today.

Nevertheless, I think your suggestion is an excellent one and I
do hope that you will follow it through.

I am now Vice-President of the Board of Managers of the Walter Reed
Memorial Association. We meet once a year in Washington in November
and last year we did erect a memorial plaque in the Hospital in
Washington where Reed died.

I am sure that General Reed, the son who lives in Washington, and
the family would participate in the event because they are very
fond of the University of Virginia.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
